div.head: Hoop Skirts vs. Hoopless Skirts
div.summary: Observing that a "marked event is transpiring in the world of Fashion," the article discusses the latest fads in women's apparel and notes the cyclical nature of styles.

div.head: Local Items--The Spring Elections
div.summary: The article lists the results of the recent elections, and asserts that "things were a little mixed up" in Chambersburg; The Democrats did not nominate a full ticket, choosing instead to place Republicans to fill it up. As a consequence, there was spirited effort among many Republicans to defeat those candidates fearing they would support Democratic initiatives. In some areas Democrats refused to vote for the fusion tickets, inserting the phrase "'can't vote for niger,'" or in some instances writing in the name of a black person.
div.note: For a full account, see the 3/20/1867 and 3/27/1867 issues of the Valley Spirit.

div.head: Local Items--Firing on an Officer
div.summary: Reports that a posse headed by Officer Houser descended upon Isaac Hentrick's residence to arrest him on a warrant issued for "threats against one of our citizens and indecently exposing his person." When the members of the group arrived, Hentricks refused to give himself up and fired five shots at them from his window, just missing one of them. Officer Houser responded by "procuring a rifle, which had the effect of bringing Hentrick to terms." The man was subsequently arrested and confined to the county jail.

div.head: Local Items--Barn Burned
div.summary: Mathew Elder's "fine large barn" near Dry Run burned down last Wednesday. Elder did manage to save his stock before the conflagration destroyed the structure, though he did lose several pieces of farm machinery and some crops. Fortunately for Elder, his insurance will cover a significant portion of his losses.

div.head: Local Items--Postmistress Appointed
div.summary: Announces that Mrs. Rice, widow of the late P. A. Rice, who was taken during Stuart's raid in 1862 and died in a southern prison, has been appointed Postmistress of Mercersburg. She will begin on April 1st.

div.head: Local Items--New Railroad
div.summary: Informs readers that the "Cumberland Valley Railroad, the South Mountain Railroad, and other wealthy corporations and individuals" are lobbying "vigorously" for approval of the proposed line from Carlisle to Caledonia Furnace.

div.head: Local Items
div.summary: At the Tenth Annual Session of the East Baltimore M. E. Conference, which met on August 13th, Rev. William Harden, formerly of Chambersburg, was elected Secretary, and Rev. J. Akers, of Mercersburg, was selected as one of the Assistant Secretaries.

div.head: Local Items--Graduated
div.summary: The article states that Samuel F. Croft, formerly of Chambersburg, graduated form the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy on August 15th.

div.head: Local Items--Confirmed
div.summary: John X. Beidler, formerly a resident of Chambersburg, was confirmed by the Senate as Collector of Customs for Montana and Idaho.

div.head: Local Items
div.summary: Announces that the Town Council appointed D. S. Fahnestock Treasurer and John A. Seiders Clerk.

div.head: Married
div.summary: On Feb. 26th, Joseph Strickler, of Illinois, and Mary K. Stouffer were married by Rev. Christian Keefer.

div.head: Married
div.summary: On Feb. 21st, William Glaser and Margaret Ellen Bitner were married by Rev. P. S. Davis.

div.head: Married
div.summary: On March 14th, Levi Steppler and Elizabeth Seibert were married by Rev. G. Roth.

div.head: Died
div.summary: On March 10th, Charlotte McKinistry died in Mercersburg. She was 62 years old.

div.head: Died
div.summary: On March 11th, Evaline C., daughter of John Downey, died. She was 15 years old.

div.head: Died
div.summary: On March 14th, Howard, infant son of Eli McCullough, died near Loudon. He was 7 months old.

div.head: Died
div.summary: On March 12th, William Gibson died at the National Hotel of consumption. He was 33 years old.

div.head: Died
div.summary: On March 11th, David French died near Spring Run. He was 48 years old.
